title: About
text:
Hello and Welcome to My Corner of the Web!
I’m embarking on an exciting adventure into the realms of data science and programming, with R as my trusty compass. This blog will serve as my digital notebook where I document my exploration of data manipulation, statistical analysis, and visualization, all through the lens of R.
As a fresh face in this field, I hope that my posts are approachable for everyone from the complete novice to the curious onlooker. My goal is to blend curiosity with learning, offering insights into topics that fascinate me.
Join me as we navigate through R’s syntax, explore its powerful libraries like ggplot2 and dplyr, and uncover the stories hidden within data. Whether you’re here to learn alongside me, share your knowledge, or just enjoy the journey, I’m thrilled you’re here. Let’s make sense of the data world together!

title: Your Document Title
text:
# Load the libraries that are going to be used
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyquant)


# Define the stock symbols. These will be pilled from yahoo finance. This is the Bloomberg Magnificent 7.
stock_symbols <- c("AAPL", "AMZN", "GOOGL", "META", "MSFT", "NVDA", "TSLA")

# Get the prices from yahoo finance using tidyquant from last year year end to date. From the original data that is pulled in, only keep the clsoing price and date for each symbol. IF there are errors, just rerun.``
stock_prices <- tq_get(stock_symbols, from="2023-12-19") %>% 
  select(symbol, date, close)

# Show the stock prices
stock_prices

# A tibble: 1,666 × 3
   symbol date       close
   <chr>  <date>     <dbl>
 1 AAPL   2023-12-19  197.
 2 AAPL   2023-12-20  195.
 3 AAPL   2023-12-21  195.
 4 AAPL   2023-12-22  194.
 5 AAPL   2023-12-26  193.
 6 AAPL   2023-12-27  193.
 7 AAPL   2023-12-28  194.
 8 AAPL   2023-12-29  193.
 9 AAPL   2024-01-02  186.
10 AAPL   2024-01-03  184.
# ℹ 1,656 more rows



theme_set(theme_tq())

ggplot(stock_prices, aes(date, close, color = symbol)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_tq()
